newsitem.title: UK: UK's Clarke says stg may hamper exports, not GDP.
newsitem.headline: UK's Clarke says stg may hamper exports, not GDP.

text.p: Britain's Chancellor of the Exchequer Kenneth Clarke said on Monday that the pound's strength could choke off export growth to an extent but would not threaten healthy economic growth.
"Healthy growth may well be checked in exports a little by the strengthening pound but will not be fundamentally damaged," Clarke told a news conference.
The pound has risen about 15 percent on a trade-weighted basis since August last year, forcing British exporters' prices higher.

Foreign exchange analysts said the prospect of an official interest rate rise soon after May Day elections, which the opposition Labour Party are in pole position to win if the opinion polls are right, will keep the pound firm.
Clarke told the news conference that he always looked at the economic data month by month when deciding monetary policy but would "quite fearlessly" raise interest rates if he thought it necessary.
"But my belief is we've set a course...to get healthy growth without it going into inflation," he said.
